heading.title: PART 2 THE DISTRICT COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 8–18L]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 2 THE DISTRICT COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 8–18L]

leg:heading.title: THE DISTRICT COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 8–18L]

p.text: There shall be a District Court of New South Wales.
The Court shall be a court of record.
There shall be a seal of the Court, and any document required by or under this or any other Act or law to be sealed or stamped with the seal of the Court shall be so sealed or stamped.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 3, s 44, s 7.

The District Courts were created to replace courts of requests, which had been created in England from the reign of James I onwards as local small debts courts dealing with the enforcement of small claims. In New South Wales courts of requests, presided over by a commissioner appointed by the Governor, were set up shortly after the establishment of the colony. This was done pursuant to the statute 10 Geo 4 No 3 (assented to 9 September 1829) which declared inter alia: “Whereas by an Act of Parliament passed in the ninth year of His Majesty George IV intituled `An Act to provide for the Administration of Justice in New South Wales and Van Diemen's Land and for the more effectual government thereof and for other purposes relating thereto' it was enacted that it should be lawful for the Governor of New South Wales with the advice of his Legislative Council by laws or ordinances to be from time to time for that purpose made and enacted to institute Courts of Civil Jurisdiction to be called `Courts of Requests' in different parts of New South Wales … [and] … Whereas it is expedient that such Courts of Requests should be instituted in certain districts or parts of the said Territory of New South Wales …”, and the statute continued: “Courts of Requests shall be holden in and for the several respective districts of Sydney, Windsor, Campbelltown, Parramatta, Maitland and Bathurst … [with] … full power and authority to hear and determine in a summary way all actions, plaints or suits for the payment and recovery of any debt, damages or matter not exceeding £10 sterling except the matter in question should relate to the title of any land, tenements, or hereditaments or the taking of any duty payable to His Majesty or to any fee of office, annual rent or other such matter where rights in future might be bound or any general right or duty and to award costs therein”

By the statute 6 Vict No 15 (1842), inter alia, the jurisdiction of courts of requests was increased to the amount of £30. At that time both courts of requests and courts of petty sessions functioned in the colony. The courts of petty sessions had been created in 1832 by the Act 3 Wm 4 No 3 and were presided over by two or more justices of the peace “sitting in open court” with jurisdiction to “take cognizance in a summary way” of all misdemeanours, and to carry out duties required to be performed by “Benches of Magistrates and Clerks of the Bench”. In 1846 by the Act 10 Vic No 10 the courts of petty sessions were invested with civil jurisdiction up to a limit of £10 (or £30 if the defendant consented in writing to the increase in jurisdiction). By the same legislation the courts of petty sessions were constituted both courts of requests and declared to be courts of record.

New South Wales District Courts were first created by the District Courts Act 1858 (22 Vict No 18), which was assented to on 12 November 1858. This Act was entitled “An Act for establishing District Courts and for enabling the Judges thereof to act as Chairmen of Quarter Sessions”. The 1842 Act 6 Vict No 15 was repealed and the District Courts established under the new Act were given “the same jurisdiction and powers in actions of replevin as to distresses for rent as are given to the Courts of Requests and Courts of Petty Sessions” by Act of Council 15 Vict No 11 s 23. It was provided that in construing the Act “the term `District' shall, if not inconsistent with the context, be taken to mean some District in and for which a District Court is holden” and s 3 of the Act empowered the Governor, with the advice of the Executive Council “to divide the Colony into Districts for the purposes of this Act”. Section 7 conferred jurisdiction on the new District Courts in “all pleas of personal actions wherein the amount claimed is not more than £200 whether on balance of account or after an admitted set-off or otherwise” but declared that the new courts had no jurisdiction where title to land or the validity of any devise bequest or limitation under any will or settlement was in question, nor where any question of seduction or criminal conversation was involved.

By 1905 the District Courts (Amendment) Act of that year raised the jurisdictional limit in common law matters to £400. The same Act also conferred jurisdiction on the District Courts in any action in which title to land was in question, provided the value of the land did not exceed the sum of £200. The Act also extended the jurisdiction of the courts beyond the pure common law causes of action by providing for District Courts to try issues of fact in equity, probate and matrimonial causes which were remitted to them by the Supreme Court. After 1905 the monetary limit on the jurisdiction of the District Courts was increased from time to time — the current limits being found in s 44 below. In 1949 (Act No 44), limited jurisdiction in equity was conferred for the first time.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 8.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 10.
The court established under this Act is a new court and constitutes one District Court for the whole of New South Wales: see DCA s 10 and [DCA s 10.5] .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 8.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 157.

The court is a court of limited statutory jurisdiction and not a superior court: Palmer v Clarke (1989) 19 NSWLR 158 at 167 ; R v Longshaw (1990) 20 NSWLR 554 at 564 ; R v Mosely (1992) 28 NSWLR 735 at 739 . The distinguishing characteristics of a superior court are summarised in R v Metal Trades Employers Assn; Ex parte Amalgamated Engineering Union, Australian Section (1951) 82 CLR 208 at 240–1 . Whatever may technically be the limits upon the need for the court to keep records, such records as it does keep are conclusive evidence of what they contain: Lee v Mallam (1910) 10 SR (NSW) 876; 27 WN (NSW) 203 at 204–5 . By s 157 of the Evidence Act 1995, evidence of a public document, that is a judgment, Act or other process of an Australian court that purports to be signed by a judge of that court, may be adduced by producing a copy: Erceg v District Court of New South Wales [2003] NSWCA 379; BC200308006 at [21] and discussed in Re Devereaux; Ex parte Power (1956) 57 SR (NSW) 253; 74 WN (NSW) 1.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 8.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Bankruptcy Act 1966.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 8.
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 Pt 1 r 6.

A convenient summary of the history of court seals in New South Wales is set out in Saffron v Delaney (1953) 53 SR (NSW) 80 . The requirement for sealing may be essential to the validity of the document required to be sealed: Re O'Sullivan; Ex parte Bank of New Zealand (1991) 30 FCR 112; 102 ALR 206 (a case under the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) and rules the wording of which in respect of sealing is comparable to s 8 ). The requirement for sealing under the rules is found in DCR Pt 1 r 6 . The manner of the use of the public seal of the state and specifically whether it is necessary for the governor personally to attend to its affixation concerning the appointment of a District Court judge is discussed in R v Lars (aka Larsson) (1994) 33 NSWLR 301; BC9405319 (CCA).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 9] s 9 Jurisdiction of the Court generally

p.text: The Court shall have a civil jurisdiction, consisting of—
its jurisdiction conferred by Part 3 ; and
the jurisdiction conferred by or under any other Act or law on the Court, not being its jurisdiction referred to in subsection (2) .
The Court shall have a criminal jurisdiction, consisting of—
its jurisdiction conferred by Part 4 ; and
the jurisdiction conferred by or under any other Act or law on the Court in its criminal jurisdiction.
[subs (2) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 Sch 2]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 9(1)(b).
(NSW) Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 65.
The provisions of s 9(1)(b) give the court jurisdiction in respect of statutory appeals: Cook v Head [1976] 1 NSWLR 176 at 187.

It is arguable that the jurisdiction of the District Court extends to judicial review under the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 65 : Obieta v Consumer, Tenancy and Trading Tribunal (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 249; BC200907371 at [8]–[12] per Hodgson JA ], at [17] per Basten JA agreeing (leave to appeal granted question undecided).
The general criminal jurisdiction of the court is noted in Jago v District Court of New South Wales (1989) 168 CLR 23 at 35; 87 ALR 577; BC8902707 .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 9.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Corporations (New South Wales) Amendment Act 1995.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001.

From 12 October 1995 the court pursuant to the Corporations (New South Wales) Amendment Act 1995 has specifically been given jurisdiction in civil matters arising under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) .

The court is an inferior court of record and therefore does not have the inherent jurisdiction derived from the royal courts of justice. However the court has all those powers which are necessary to enable it to act effectively within its jurisdiction and which are necessary, in that context, to secure the proper administration of justice: see generally Overton v Loukides [1970] VR 462 ; Bogeta Pty Ltd v Wales [1977] 1 NSWLR 139 at 148–9 ; John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd (recs and mgrs apptd) v Local Court of New South Wales (1991) 26 NSWLR 131; 26 ALD 471 ; Director-General, Dept of Community Services v Boehm (NSWSC, Santow J, No 2836/97, 13 August 1997, unreported, BC9703792); AVS Australian Venue Security Services Pty Ltd v Criminale [2006] NSWCA 368; BC200610504 esp at [25], [28]–[36] (District Court has no inherent/incidental power to set aside default judgment). See also “The Inherent Jurisdiction of the Court” (1983) 57 ALJ 449 esp at 456 and the annotations at [DCA s 156.5] ff.

The distinction between implied power (which the court does have) and inherent jurisdiction (which it does not have) is important. The implied power is confined to whatever may be necessary to effectively exercise an expressly conferred power. “Necessary” in this sense means a power to make orders which are reasonably required or legally ancillary to the accomplishment of the express or specific power: Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 451–2; 162 ALR 336 at 347; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . Inherent jurisdiction (such as the Supreme Court has) refers to unexpressed powers identified by reference to the unlimited powers of the courts at Westminster. The District Court unlike the Supreme Court (a superior court) does not have a general responsibility for the administration of justice beyond the confines of its jurisdiction: Grassby v R (1989) 168 CLR 1 at 16–17; 87 ALR 618 at 627–9; [1989] HCA 45; BC8902704 ; Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 451–2; 162 ALR 336 at 347; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . In John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v District Court of New South Wales (2004) 61 NSWLR 344; 50 ACSR 380 ; [2004] NSWCA 324; BC200406122 , a District Court judge made orders suppressing the publication of a verdict relating to breaches of the Corporations Law. It was held that the District Court did not have an express power to make a non-publication order, only by implication and by necessity from the conferral of a criminal jurisdiction; that the District Court had no implied power to order non-publication of a verdict: adjournments and stays were ordinarily sufficient to ensure a fair trial; and that the District Court had no power to make a non-publication order directed only to persons unrelated to the proceedings (eg the media).
Legislation cited in [DCA s 9.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 10(1) , s 5(2).

The rules of court are taken to include the UCPR to the extent to which they are applicable in the District Court: CPA s 10(1) . However, nothing in the uniform rules extends the jurisdiction of the District Court except to the extent to which the CPA expressly so provides: CPA s 5(2) .
The Court, wherever sitting, shall, subject to this Act, have jurisdiction throughout the whole of New South Wales.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 10.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 ss 8, 9.

In contrast with the position which applied under earlier legislation this section, together with ss 8 and 9 , establishes one District Court for the whole of New South Wales and expressly provides that the jurisdiction of the court is statewide irrespective of the place where the cause of action arose or the usual place of residence of the parties. Formerly, the District Courts had jurisdiction only within the geographical limits or districts defined by the governor's proclamation: see, for example, the District Courts Act 1912 s 5 . And even though s 15 of that Act provided that a person appointed as a judge of a District Court was thereby constituted a judge of every District Court the section also went on to direct that a judge should only exercise his jurisdiction in the districts appointed by the governor. Apparently it was not until after 1945 that it became the custom for such an appointment to be made in respect of all districts.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 11] s 11 Single Judge to constitute the Court

leg:heading.title: Single Judge to constitute the Court

p.text: All civil and criminal proceedings in the Court, and all business arising out of any such proceedings, shall, subject to this Act and the Jury Act, 1977 , be heard and disposed of before a Judge, who shall constitute the Court.
[subs (1) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Schs 2, 8]

Subsection (1) does not affect the provisions of this Act and the civil or criminal procedure rules concerning the hearing and disposal of civil and criminal proceedings and business before a registrar or other officer of the Court.
[subs (2) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 11.5] Death or incapacity of judge

p.text: Apart from instances where there is a contrary statutory provision: for example, Chua v Chua [1963] 1 All ER 102; [1962] 1 WLR 1464; the ordinary rule is that once the hearing of proceedings has been commenced the same members of the court ought to conduct the hearing to the conclusion of the proceedings: R v Marrington (1850) 1 Legge 643; Ex parte Ryan (1864) 3 SCR (NSW) 221: Coleshill v Manchester Corp [1928] 1 KB 776; Fulker v Fulker [1936] 3 All ER 636; Whittle v Whittle [1939] 1 All ER 374; Munday v Munday [1954] 2 All ER 667; [1954] 1 WLR 1078. There is an exception to this general rule where a severable aspect of the proceedings, for example, costs, is capable of being dealt with by a reconstituted court: Orr v Holmes (1948) 76 CLR 632 at 637–8; 22 ALJR 283 ; Wentworth v Rogers (No 3) (1986) 6 NSWLR 642 at 649. There are also cases where a reconstituted court has been asked to conduct the proceedings on the basis of the transcript of evidence given at the earlier hearing: Brennan v Brennan (1953) 89 CLR 129; [1953] ALR 528 ; Re British Reinforced Concrete Engineering Co Ltd's Application (1929) 45 TLR 186 ; Bolton v Bolton [1949] 2 All ER 908. Although such a course is undesirable where there is a serious conflict of evidence (McCormack v FCT (1979) 143 CLR 284; 23 ALR 583 ) or where the court is constituted by a judge and jury (Coleshill v Manchester Corp [1928] 1 KB 776; Re British Reinforced Concrete Engineering Co Ltd's Application (1929) 45 TLR 186 ) it is not correct to say that there is no jurisdiction for the court to conduct the proceedings in this way in an appropriate case: Wentworth v Rogers (No 3), above. Where the parties have acquiesced in, or waived the irregularity, they will not normally be heard later to complain of it: Wentworth v Rogers (No 3), above; Donelian v Donalian [2002] NSWSC 696; BC200205134 (in part-heard proceedings the magistrate was ill. Another magistrate read the transcript and was willing to hear the balance of the proceedings. Both parties consented. The resulting judgment was appealed — not challenging the propriety of continuation before the new magistrate but asserting that the change in magistrate after the plaintiff had completed her examination-in-chief disadvantaged the plaintiff by reason of the fact that the magistrate did not have the benefit of seeing and hearing her evidence-in-chief — held, new trial refused).
